Typically=A0Kanezane's personally made swords will have a showa stamp=A0and=
 feature a kakihan (stamped personal seal)=A0following the=A0mei on the nak=
ago. The outline of his kakihan resembles the shape of a turtle with the Za=
ne character in the center. The fact that=A0there is=A0a seki stamp=A0leave=
s little doubt that this is a production sword. 
regards, Franco

Kanesane swords do have a fairly good following for a showato =
in part thanks 
to the Fuller and Gregory book and the fact that most were =
water quenched. A 
broken tip unfortunately <WBR>will require a foundation =
polish making it 
difficult to get away with anything short of a costly pol=
ish an good polisher. 

regards, Franco>>

Franco:

The amount of money I h=
ave invested in this blade is a whole $40.00 US. The 
amount of material lo=
ss at the Kissaki having looked at it with my glasses 
on is less than 3/64=
" to my tired old eyes.

d and remounted, now the 
question is to whom do I send it to for the polis=
h. Fed Lohman has a gentleman 
who does polishing but I do not know of anyo=
ne who has used him and I do not 
want this blade ruined as I already saved=
 it for a horrible fate as a yard 
work tool...

There is a lot of activity=
 (due to the water/brine quenching) along the 
Hamon that I can still see a=
 bit though the very light surface oxidation.. I 
could be wrong but I feel=
 that it could benefit from restoration, even as a 
simple "what the heck, =
let's do it" type of project.

I just don't want to be trying to make a sil=
k purse out of a sow's ear if 
you know what I mean... I will try to get so=

did =
make quite a few blades personally, as well as supervising his production 
=
company, how do I tell for sure if this is a production blade or one he

de himslef. I am leaning towards the former due to the Seki stamp on the

akago.
